Introduction

Pregnancy losses are common, with up to a third of all pregnancies ending with a miscarriage, and many women experiencing one miscarriage during their reproductive ages.  In addition, having a miscarriage between term pregnancies is also common.

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), or recurrent miscarriage, is uncommon and is defined by consecutive pregnancy losses.  Clinically, RPL is poorly defined but generally refers to â‰¥3 consecutive spontaneous abortions at <20 weeks gestation.  However, because of the significant psychological impact of pregnancy loss, a work-up is typically begun following â‰¥2 clinical pregnancies (ie, ultrasound or histopathologic proven pregnancy).

Etiologies

RPL is caused by many different etiologies that may act in isolation or in conjunction with one another.  Key mechanisms include:

Uterine causes

Uterine anomalies account for 10% to 50% of RPL cases and are classified as either congenital or acquired.

Congenital uterine anomalies include (

figure 1
):

  • Septate uterus:  The uterine anomaly most commonly associated with RPL.  Uterine septa have a relatively low blood supply; therefore, when embryo implantation occurs on the septum, the implantation is poorly vascularized, which leads to abnormal development and early pregnancy loss.
  • Unicornuate or bicornuate uterus:  These congenital uterine anomalies do not allow for normal uterine distention with fetal growth, leading to possible increased inflammation and decreased progesterone supply, resulting in pregnancy loss.

Acquired uterine abnormalities include:

  • Intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome) (
    figure 2
    ):  Intrauterine adhesions (synechiae) most commonly develop secondary to uterine curettage (ie, dilation and curettage) performed for pregnancy complications (eg, retained products of conception, postpartum hemorrhage).  Synechiae lead to pregnancy loss because not enough normal endometrium remains to support fetal growth development.
  • Uterine leiomyoma (
    figure 3
    ):  Fibroids can increase in size during reproductive years (as they are estrogen-dependent); submucosal and intracavitary fibroids are particularly associated with RPL because they cause abnormal intrauterine anatomy by extending into the uterine cavity and disrupting the normal endometrium.  This condition compromises embryo implantation or growth, likely due to decreased endometrial thickness and the reduced vascularity of the fibroid.

Endocrine disorders

Endocrine factors account for RPL in 15% to 60% of cases.  Particular conditions that predispose to RPL include:

  • Diabetes mellitus:  Poorly controlled diabetes (hemoglobin A1c > 8%) increases RPL risk primarily through hyperglycemia and vascular disease, which cause poor implantation and placental development.  Of note, patients with well-controlled diabetes mellitus do not have an increased risk of RPL.
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS):  PCOS most likely increases RPL risk through elevated serum LH and testosterone levels and insulin resistance.  The combination of these changes cause delayed ovulation and possible unfavorable endometrial changes that result in pregnancy loss.
  • Thyroid dysfunction and hyperprolactinemia:  Poorly controlled disease and hyperprolactinemia increases the risk of RPL, likely through ovulatory dysfunction and subsequent endometrial changes that impair implantation.

Immunologic factors

Clinically, the most important immunologic cause of RPL is antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), which is characterized by antiphospholipid antibodies (eg, lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibodies), venous and arterial thrombosis, and poor pregnancy outcomes (RPL, early preeclampsia with severe features [ie, <34 weeks gestation]) (

).  APS is thought to cause impaired trophoblast proliferation, thrombosis in placental vessels, inflammation, and impaired angiogenesisâ€”all of which contribute to increased risk of RPL.

Genetic factors

Genetic abnormalities are the primary cause of sporadic early pregnancy loss.  However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to maternal or paternal chromosomal abnormalities account for only 2%-5% of cases of RPL.  The most frequently implicated abnormality is a balanced reciprocal translocation, which can include Robertsonian translocations.  With balanced reciprocal translocations, the parental carrier is asymptomatic but produces unbalanced gametes that can result in trisomy or monosomy following fertilization, leading to RPL (

figure 4
).

Other genetic abnormalities include chromosomal deletions, inversions, and mosaicism, which can lead to repeated conception of zygotes with chromosomal abnormalities and RPL (

figure 5
).

Idiopathic

Despite a full evaluation for possible underlying etiologies, no specific etiology is identified in about 50% of couples with RPL.

Evaluation

The evaluation for RPL begins with a detailed medical history, with particular attention to the gestational age of the loss, gynecologic conditions, and medical comorbidities.  A combination of these factors can help identify a particular etiology; for example, chromosomal abnormalities and endocrine disorders usually lead to RPL at earlier gestational ages than anatomic abnormalities or immunologic conditions.

Based on history and physical examination, patients with RPL undergo individualized laboratory evaluation and imaging to help identify and treat underlying causes.

Laboratory evaluation

  • Genetic testing:  A karyotype analysis is a relatively low-yield test and is typically reserved for couples where no alternative cause of RPL is identified.  When possible, genetic evaluation of products of conception (ie, pregnancy tissue) should be performed following a miscarriage.
  • Thyroid function testing with thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies:  These tests are performed in both symptomatic and asymptomatic patients, as both subclinical hypothyroidism and euthroid with TPO antibodies are at increased risk of RPL.
  • APS testing:  Laboratory testing is performed in patients with clinical suspicion, including those with RPL and either a vascular thrombosis or pregnancy complication (eg, pregnancy loss, preterm delivery due to preeclampsia with severe features or placental insufficiency).  A positive laboratory evaluation requires positive antiphospholipid antibodies on â‰¥2 tests performed â‰¥12 weeks apart.

Imaging studies

Uterine anatomy evaluation is performed on all patients with RPL and includes an initial transvaginal ultrasound.  In many patients, a saline infusion sonohysterogram is also performed to assess the uterine anatomy for abnormalities (eg, submucosal leiomyoma, endometrial polyp) (

figure 6
).

An alternative imaging modality is a hysterosalpingogram (HSG), which can delineate the structural abnormalities in the uterine cavity (eg, septate uterus (

figure 7
), bicornuate uterus (
figure 8
), synechiae) and also allows assessment of fallopian tube patency.  However, HSG does not visualize the outer uterine contour, which may limit the ability to distinguish between various congenital uterine anomalies.

Management

The management of RPL is dependent on the underlying etiology.  However, all patients with RPL should be offered psychological counseling and support groups regardless of the etiology.

Genetic abnormalities

Genetic counseling can provide recurrence risk and other implications of the specific abnormality identified.  In vitro fertilization (IVF) with preimplantation genetic testing or the use of donor sperm or oocytes can reduce the risk of an embryo with a genetic abnormality.

Uterine abnormalities

Uterine septum, intrauterine adhesions, and submucosal/intracavitary fibroids can be surgically corrected with operative hysteroscopy to create a normal uterine cavity, reducing rates of miscarriage.  Patients with other anomalies (eg, bicornuate uterus) may require more advanced procedures to create a normal cavity or require the use of a gestational carrier.

Endocrine disorders

Hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism treatment to achieve normal hormone levels reduces the risk of miscarriage.  Tight glycemic control reduces risk in patients with diabetes mellitus.

Immunologic factors

Low-dose aspirin and either heparin or low molecular weight heparin are used in patients with APS to prevent thrombosis and reduce risk of pregnancy loss.

Idiopathic

Unexplained RPL may be treated with IVF and oocyte donation as impaired egg quality may contribute to unexplained RPL.

Prognosis

The prognosis for RPL varies based on the underlying etiology.  However, 60% to 80% of couples eventually achieve a successful pregnancy.  Uterine anomalies corrected surgically are generally followed by good outcomes.  IVF with preimplantation genetic screening greatly improves the chances of a live birth in the case of a heritable parental genetic abnormality.  Patients with endocrine diseases and APS require ongoing management to optimize medical control of their conditions and reduce the risk of pregnancy loss.  These conditions also frequently predispose to additional pregnancy complications (eg, preeclampsia, thrombosis, fetal growth restriction) and require close monitoring throughout pregnancy.

Summary

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL), or recurrent miscarriage, is poorly defined but generally refers to â‰¥3 consecutive spontaneous abortions at <20 weeks gestation.  Causes of RPL are multifactorial and include uterine anomalies, endocrine abnormalities, and immunologic factors; however, up to 50% of cases are idiopathic.
